b fagan,

C3 is helpful because the charts allow all to plainly see what the data informs, thus one can quickly ascertain the realities, or take all the time needed to wade into the data such as we might do.

You seem to miss that all the major GCM's say the heat will accumulate in the troposphere and not in the oceans, if the heat is in the oceans then the models are invalidated, and the simple settled physics of our climate system terribly misunderstood, not that the faithful care too much about actual science (or the fact that the heat has not been proved to be in the oceans). Here is Phil Jones speaking about how the SST's have been bastardized to match the cooked-up data sets and not invalidate them:

http://wattsupwiththat.com/2014/01/17/phil-jones-2012-video-talks-about-...

The NOAA site you link to starts the world at 1955, there was far more ocean warming before 1955 than after 1955. From NOAA:

http://c3headlines.typepad.com/.a/6a010536b58035970c01a73d761370970d-pi

Your description of the last decade being the hottest ever is only the case using data sets which have had the past cooled and the more recent years warmed, these adjustments have been posted here by me several times, if you choose to ignore them that too would suggest a lack of regard for actual science, additionally, we know it was much hotter globally at least 3 times prior in this interglacial, even in the oceans.

@Dan Stackhouse:  Sorry to see you criticizing Snowden.  Of course he lied about stealing the information, but that isn't what Alexander meant.  Has Snowden lied to _us_?  I don't know that he has.  And what evidence (hard evidence, not inference from suppositions about what Putin does) is there that he did what Putin commanded him to?  I would be a lot more cautious about making up scenarios.  I don't know Snowden, I don't know what drives him, I don't know what pressures he may be subjected to in Russia (which he can't leave because we won't let him), but I know I don't know and I know he's done all U.S. citizens a huge favor by forcing not only us but our government to deal with the fact of constant, intrusive, comprehensive, illegal (yes it was illegal) spying by our government on us, the people, supposedly the bosses of our democratic system.

Cowtan and Way ... one of the worst papers of the recent period:

"The Cowtan and Way (2013) revisions to the HADCRUT4 data do nothing to explain the absence of warming that is occurring in the non-polar regions during the hiatus period. Those non-polar regions cover about 90% of the planet and it’s there that climate models cannot explain the slowdown and absence of warming. The Cowtan and Way revisions also exaggerate the warming at the poles which further undermines the current generation of climate models, because the models are unable to explain the observed warming at the poles. That is, the models are still not capable of properly simulating polar amplification.

Those who promote the Cowtan and Way (2013) revisions to the HADCRUT4 data don’t understand where the hiatus is taking place and they don’t understand the model failings at simulating polar amplification—or—they are intentionally being misleading."

http://wattsupwiththat.com/2014/02/22/cowtan-and-way-2013-adjustments-ex...

Amazing! ...and disconcerting. How can it be that by listening to Mr. Snowden's  argument and comparing it to our governments own that I can better understand Mr. Snowden's position and explanation for leaking confidential government documents. The governments response is accusatory and frighteningly sounds like a wounded canine animal who's found their teeth has been pulled out. I for one am glad that there was a conscious mind in a un-supervised branch of our government to actually speak out and shift the public eye from irrelevant celebrity life stories to something that affects every American citizen's human rights. To think that just around four years ago there was a branch of government snooping into everyone's online life without the individuals consent nor awareness... well, disturbing thoughts aside, Mr. Snowden should be applauded for shaking up a arrogant government that violated American's privacy. Now congress has something that they actually care about that will actually help us protect our online privacy.

Gotta say: Kerry's response appalled me. I get the feeling that he would prefer Snowdon stay out of the country, and certainly away from our legal system. Due process would certainly shine a lot of light into dark corners.

To Cat: I am touched by your words. Perhaps you can imagine each of her words as seeds, planted in the many hundreds of thousands, perhaps millions, of people whom she touched, and that these seeds will grow and continue on without end... she lives on in our hearts and our deeds and our words, neverending... The form has changed, the gift keeps giving.

...Caged Bird... was the first book I was assigned in college - it has stayed with me & I still have it (beside my "pocket copy" of Phenomenal Woman). Reading any phrase is like hearing her voice & feeling her spirit - so beautiful.  May you rest in peace Ms. Angelou.

Three were stabbed or slashed to death, three were shot to death, and seven more were wounded by gunfire.  We don't know what the circumstances were at his apartment that permitted a self-admitted weakling to stab or slash his three roommates, but I have no doubt if the weakling had chosen to use a knife in public to commit his heinous act, there would've much less carnage.

Maya Angelou would have mattered to our society had she not been a poet, in part because she was so much more and in part because she rose up from the depths of personal hardship imposed on her at a very young age and because the stain of racism is buried deep in the American soul, which she also overcame with determination and, at times, joyously. I give further thanks that she was a poet, too, and that her passing is noted as few others writers of any sort are in our restless, pushy and often uncaring world.

Poetry matters because it represents humanity reaching for transcendent expression and searching for meaning in our lives, which, by their finding, can, yes, lift us up bit by bit above the fearful brutality and banality of life reminding us to live for a purpose. Thank you, Ms. Angelou.

Really? Please, do tell me how your imagined perception of "gun absolutists" have threatened ANYONE with violence.

Let's agree that seriously mentally ill and other dangerous, irresponsible folks do not need to be driving cars.

But let's also agree that right now it is much easier to deny someone the legal ability to drive a car than it is to deny them access to a gun. I read this sick kid's manifesto. His dream of killing started when he went to a gun range one afternoon and started shooting at targets. He decided then that if his life didn't turn around, he would get guns and have his day of retribution.

Oddly, he didn't decide that at a knife store or a car dealership. Maybe it's the idea that many guns are marketed on how well they kill human beings?

All rights have limits, and gun rights have limits too, you cannot for instance just go buy a machine gun. You cannot use fighting words, you cannot publish national security materials, you cannot abuse people under the cover of religion. You can view pornography, but you cannot display it in public. Violent civil unrest is not tolerated. The right to own guns is in part infringed upon, and that infringement can be intelligently increased to provide more public safety, without causing gun owners any substantive harm.

Balances are drawn, some local, some state, some Federal. It's the only the unchallenged money of the NRA that keeps the gun hobby sacrosanct, not some inherent sacredness of unregulated gun ownership.

There is no way to eliminate these gun acts without infringing on the right to own guns. Just like the freedom of speech, assembly an press, when you allow these freedoms, you will encounter the few who abuse these rights. Legislating out all abuses will also so severely limit the freedoms. For example-pornography, violent civil unrest- we put up with this because legislating them out would absolutely infringe on our rights and freedoms.

Of course the politicians will sponsor any legislature in the heat of the moment to build their own careers without thinking about the long term problems the legislations will cause.

Where did you get the 29% figure? It's wrong. Here's a link to the recent Gallup poll: http://www.gallup.com/poll/165563/remains-divided-passing-stricter-gun-l... which states 49% of US adults want tighter gun control.
